1.0	Executive Summary (§68.155)

1.1 	Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies (68.155(a)) 

Metl-Span is committed to employee, public, and environmental safety.  This commitment is demonstrated by Metl-Span's comprehensive accidental release prevention program.  It is Metl-Span's policy to implement appropriate controls to prevent possible releases of regulated substances. If such releases were to occur, the Mattoon Fire Department would response to the release. Metl-Span has coordinated emergency response actions with the Mattoon Fire Department and has provided information to the Coles County LEPC regarding regulated substances our plant.

1.2 	The Stationary Source and the Regulated Substances Handled (§68.155(b)) 

Metl-Span manufacturers Insulated Metal Panels (IMPs) at its facility in Mattoon, Illinois. IMPs are lightweight composite exterior wall and roof panels with metal skins and an insulating foam core. Three raw materials are used to produce the foam core of the panels: diphenyl methane diisocyanurate (MDI), polyol, and the blowing agent 1,1-difluoroethane. The 1,1-difluroethane is the only regulated substance present at the facility. The maximum inventory of 1,1-difluoroethane that is expected to be present in this facility, based on process and operational requirements, is 75,000 pounds (rounded up to two significant digits for reporting purposes). The 1,1-difluoroethane is stored in 12,000-gallon bulk storage tank.

1.3 	The General Accidental Release Prevention Program and the Chemical Specific Prevention Steps (§68.155(c))  

Our facility has taken the following steps as required by 40 CFR Part 68 of the EPA regulations. The pentane process is subject to the OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) Standard under 29 CFR 1910.119. The following sections briefly describe the elements of the release prevention program that is in place at our facility.  

Process Safety Information

Metl-Span has compiled the relevant

data as described in OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) Standard under 29 CFR 1910.119(d).  Included within this compilation is the electrical classification, materials of construction, safety systems, ventilation system design, and design codes and standards employed.  The information contained within the Process Safety Information is utilized in conducting process hazard analysis.

Process Hazard Analysis

Our facility conducts comprehensive studies to ensure that hazards associated with our process are identified and controlled efficiently. The hazard and operability (HAZOP) Guideword and What-If/Checklists methods were used to carry out these analyses . The studies are undertaken by a team of qualified personnel with expertise in engineering and process operations and are revalidated at a regular interval of every five (5) years. Any findings related to the process hazard analyses are addressed in a timely manner.  

Operating Procedures  

Metl-Span maintains written operating procedures. These procedures address the various modes of operation such as initial start-up, normal operations, temporary operations, emergency shutdown, emergency operations, normal shutdown, and start-up after a turnaround. The information is regularly reviewed and is readily accessible to operators involved in the process.  
 
Training

Our facility has a comprehensive training program in place to ensure that employees who are operating processes are competent in the operating procedures associated with those processes. New employees receive basic classroom training in process operations, followed by on-the job supervision until they are deemed competent to work independently. Refresher training on operating procedures is provided at least every three years, and more frequently as needed.  
 
Mechanical Integrity

Metl-Span carries out documented maintenance checks on process equipment to ensure proper operation. Process equipment examined by these checks includes pr

essure vessels, piping systems, relief and vent systems, emergency shutdown systems, controls, and pumps. Maintenance operations are carried out by qualified personnel with previous training in maintenance practices. Furthermore, these personnel are given specialized training as needed. Any equipment deficiencies identified by the maintenance checks are corrected in a safe and timely manner.  
 
Management of Change

Written procedures are in place at Metl-Span to manage changes in process chemicals, technology, equipment and processes. Process operators, maintenance personnel, or any other employees whose job tasks are affected by a modification in process operations are promptly made aware of and given training to deal with the modifications.  
 
Pre-Startup Reviews

Pre-startup safety reviews related to new processes and to modification of established processes are conducted as a regular practice at Metl-Span. These reviews are conducted to confirm that construction, equipment, operating and maintenance procedures are suitable for safe start-up prior to placing equipment into operation.  
 
Compliance Audits

Metl-Span conducts audits on a regular basis to determine whether the provisions set out under the RMP regulation are being implemented. These audits are carried out at least every three years and any corrective actions required as a result of the audits are undertaken in a safe and prompt manner.  
 
Incident Investigation

Metl-Span promptly investigates any incident that has resulted in, or could reasonably result in a catastrophic release of a regulated substance. These investigations are undertaken to identify the situation leading to the incident as well as any corrective actions to prevent the release from recurring. All incident reports are retained for a minimum of 5 years.  
 
Employee Participation
  
Metl-Span believes that process safety management and accident prevention are a team effort. Company employees are strongly urge

d to express their views concerning accident prevention issues and to recommend improvements. In addition, our employees have access to all information created as part of the facility's implementation of the RMP regulation, including information resulting from process hazard analyses in particular.  
 
Contractors

On occasion, our company hires contractors to conduct specialized maintenance and construction activities. Prior to selecting a contractor, a thorough evaluation of the contractor's safety performance is completed. Metl-Span has a strict policy of informing contractors of known potential hazards related to the contractor's work and the process. Contractors are also informed of all the procedures for emergency notification and evacuation, should an accidental release of a regulated substance occur.  
 
1.4 	Five-Year Accident History (§68.155(d)) 

Metl-Span has not had any reportable incidents during the past five (5) years.  
 
1.5 	Emergency Response Plan (§68.155(e)) 

Metl-Span does not have an emergency response plan and is a non-responding facility. Metl-Span has coordinated emergency response actions with the Mattoon Fire Department and has provided information to the Coles County LEPC regarding regulated substances the facility. Metl-Span has developed an emergency action plan that includes procedures for informing the public and local response agencies of a chemical release. 

1.6 	Planned Changes to Improve Safety (§68.155(f)) 

Several developments and findings have resulted from the implementation of the various elements of our accidental release prevention program. We will continue our regular reviews of the 1,1-difluoroethane system and procedures. We will also continue our annual notification and evacuation drills.
